text: hi everyone - any dead tail here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new Flying
Lotus record your dead Flying Lotus is a
West Coast music producer known for his
incredibly forward-thinking fusion of
jazz
electronic music hip hop he is also a
label head over at brain feeder records
many people consider him to have dropped
albums that are modern classics like Los
Angeles and cosma grandma and on his
fifth album here he is following up what
I consider to be one of the more
underwhelming records in his discography
until the quiet comes a record where I
think stylistically he was treading a
little bit of water some songs on this
album sounded like they could have come
off of his pattern grid world EP but
this album also features some of his
most just subtle and toned down material
yet it just kind of fell into the
background for me whenever I would play
it which is kind of an issue I have with
many brain feeder records releases so I
walked away from this project looking
forward to flylo's next project hoping
for something a little more lively a
little more refreshing and with your
dead I got that one of the most notable
changes right from the get-go on this
album is that there are more vocal
features on this LP some honest-to-god
rap verses from Kendrick Lamar and Snoop
Dogg angel dear Dorian of Dirty
Projectors Fame lands on this record
Nicki Randa who is a prior collaborator
with Flying Lotus and Thundercat as well
who is not only on this album vocally
but basically as well I'm sure and as if
we didn't see this coming Flying Lotus
also appears on this record vocally as
his low-pitched alter-ego captain Murphy
who many of you may remember from his
once anonymous solo effort not too long
ago something else to note with this
record is that it's 38 minutes one of
the shorter albums and flylo's
discography thus far but I also think
you are dead is one of flylo's most
upbeat and active albums as well I think
this record has the jazzy density of
Kozma grandma without all the meandering
and the and the atmosphere the music
that occurs on this record
very tangible it's very bold it's very
forceful this record twists and turns
and tumbles and flips like a gymnast but
an issue that I think some people may
have with this album is that some of the
tracks some of the musical passages are
rather short they're kind of brief they
build up to a moment or they create an
idea but as soon as that idea is
established it's not really fleshed out
as much as it is just transformed into
something else there are a lot of
one-minute tracks on this record and in
that regard this album can be compared
to something like J Dilla's doughnuts or
even a mad lib instrumental album but I
think a lot of the pieces of this sonic
ear candy though it may be short
effectively builds off of one another
enhances one another some of the short
but amazing musical experiences that
these little tracks bring and are
incredible right from the start of this
record the intro where we're getting
these heavy orchestral strings just this
dense instrumentation it's so huge it's
so massive I just really feel it and
even though the song ends in about a
minute 24 it glides quite perfectly into
the next track which introduces some
great bass lines so the killer drums
some good keys and this jazz fusion feel
gets just turned up the heat gets turned
up on the next song cold dead which is
just some explosive jazz rock some
distorted riffs on this track mixed with
these atmospheric musical passages of
saxophone and keyboards this album
really is flying lotuses brew or
even his music is one note coming up not
too soon after this track is never catch
me with Kendrick Lamar I did a track
review for this song I will link it at
the end of this video you can watch it
there I'm not going to dive too much
deeper into my thoughts on this track
here but in that track review I thought
this track while good not amazing but
good would sound better in the context
of this album and in fact that happens
when this song comes on it's like a fog
or a smoke clears or some significant
occurrence occurs it's like Cinderella
and you're watching this woman in a
beautiful gown just come down the
stairway ready to have fun at the ball
it's not like you're just
one tiny unfinished song after another
with your dead if you just completely
ignore the tracklisting and don't look
at the tracklisting while you're
listening to this album the entire
record sounds like one holistic piece it
may jump around a little bit but it
features some interesting and nicely
crafted segues this is a sensation I
also get from until the quiet comes but
it feels so much stronger on your dead
this album is easily flying lotuses most
holistic project yet and even though I
love that about this record and I think
this is a fantastic record it's not
without its underwhelming moments which
come here and there it's a handful
attracts namely dead man's Tetris with
Snoop Dogg his verse his guest verse is
kind of underwhelming it's not really
anything to write home about Plus for
whatever reason this instrumental is far
more modulated especially toward the end
than any other beat on this record kind
of ruins the flavor of the track for me
anyway but it's not like this record
ever hits a lull anywhere every time I
find a track that it's just okay the
album picks right back up with a great
song it does so right here with Turkey
dog coma which features some incredible
drumming and there is great drumming all
over this record some great rhythms all
over this record but here particularly
the rhythms are intense moving from
there we have the lovely and amazing
vocal interlude cornice the Terminator
really chilling in heavenly song I love
the group vocals on this track they're
absolutely stunning Flying Lotus is
doing a better and better job with each
record just honing and crafting and
finding gorgeous sounds Flying Lotus
continues to weave this really cohesive
musical tapestry tapestry with the song
Turtles which features some great hand
percussion some blissful female vocals
some ascending and descending bass lines
ready or not which kind of feels like a
little introspective bit of mid-90s IDM
with a really quirky drum loop that you
know only Flying Lotus would use descent
into madness with Thundercat is
fantastic melodically and chord wise as
well to me this kind of feels like an
interlude that would land on like a King
Crimson album and Thundercats typically
falsetto Vogel
are very nice on this track then
immediately after we get another vocal
appearance from captain Murphy or Flying
Lotus himself and he is singing here in
falsetto as well it's like a bit of
Warped soul music from the 70s or the
80s it's kind of funky but kind of slow
and strange as well and he's singing
about pills and just generally being
unhappy to me the song kind of feels
like what Tyler the Creator wishes some
of his songs sounded like and this song
is a serious risk it's like the weirdest
track on the entire LP but my one
disappointment with it is not that the
experiment fails but Flying Lotus just
fades it out which is just oh he was
doing so well making one track segue to
another why would you just flush this
one down the toilet if you're gonna do
something this weird stick with it
finish it the second last track on this
LP is it is incredibly orchestral just
like the intro it kind of glides into a
an anticlimactic closer but I still
ended up loving this LP it was a serious
journey it was colorful and varied and
dynamic had a lot of personality each
song had its own little unique direction
and flavor and yet it just came together
so well I'm giving this record a strong
8 to a light 9 I'm loving it I'm feeling
it transition if you give in this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana Flying Lotus forever
